identified-content.object.title: Longest Silence, The: A Life In Fishing (Book)

abstract.p: Mary Grace Butler reviews book The Longest Silence: A Life in Fishing by Thomas McGuane (S)

block.p: Fishing, like life, is a series of small events that, with luck, can produce large results. In ''The Longest Silence,'' a collection of more than 30 essays, the novelist Thomas McGuane takes us with him as he fishes all over the world, seemingly with no constraints of money or time, and often accompanied by famous names. His observations on the mechanics of fishing are entertaining as well as technical, but it is the gentle, elegiac descriptions laced with crisp opinion that draw the reader in -- trips to Fall River to fish with Uncle Bill and Cousin Fred, fishing with other McGuanes in Ireland, days in Key West, once ''a great and corrupt gardenia of an island,'' or in Idaho, where ''short memories and hit-and-run management techniques'' have damaged rivers. McGuane has little patience for the pretentious, complaining of those who ''scramble to name flies and knots after themselves with a self-aggrandizing ardor unknown since the Borgia popes'' and laments that modern fisherfolk, in Izaak Walton's words, are ''no longer fitted for quietness and contemplation.''
